Comments: This solution addresses both plastic waste prediction and optimal recycling program selection. It uses linear regression and a landfill density function to estimate plastic volume in landfills. For recycling programs, it considers participation rates based on socioeconomic factors and calculates costs for different program types (drop-off, curbside, single-stream, pre-sorted). The response is well-organized, detailed, and uses a variety of data sources.

Q1.Definition: Extrapolated to predict the amount of plastic that will be festering in landfills at the end of the next decade.
Assumption: Economic conditions will remain relatively stable for the next ten years.
Combustion rate for total municipal waste has remained constant from 1960 to the present.
Q1.Model: Linear regression for waste generation, combined with a non-constant landfill density function (p(d) \= .2485\*d lbs/ft^4+36.05 lbs/ft^3) derived from experimental data.  Calculates total municipal waste and plastic waste sent to landfills, then uses density to estimate volume.
Q1.Results: The volume of plastic alone in our country's landfills (assuming a uniform depth of 200 ft) will equal about 7.10\*10^9 cubic meters by 2023.
Q1.Sensitivity Analysis: Not explicitly performed, but the linearity assumption and constant recovery rate are potential sources of error.
Strength and Weakness: Strength: Uses a non-constant density function, which is more realistic than a simple density calculation.
Strength: Considers both total municipal waste and plastic waste.
Strength: Clearly explains the methodology and calculations.
Weakness: Relies on several assumptions, including constant recovery and combustion rates.
Weakness: Assumes a uniform landfill depth.

Q2.Definition: Identifies the optimal recycling program for any US city, working within the city' budget and the likelihood of its residents to participate in the recycling program.
Assumption: Population demographics such as race and age do not factor into the tendency to recycle.
New program will be as effective as an older program.
Average resident housing situation will be constant between cities.
Data from St. Paul, MN is used as average data.
Q2.Model: Predicts participation rate based on average home value and percentage of population with a bachelor's degree.  Uses weighted average of these two factors.  Then calculates program costs (drop-off, curbside single-stream weekly/biweekly, curbside pre-sorted weekly/biweekly) based on population, participation rate, and cost per ton. Compares costs to a predicted municipal budget for recycling ($6.64 per person).
Q2.Sensitivity Analysis: Not explicitly performed, but the model considers different program types and selects the best fit based on cost and participation.
Strength and Weakness: Strength: Considers both participation rate and cost.
Strength: Uses real-world data to predict participation.
Strength: Provides a clear methodology for selecting the optimal program.
Weakness: Relies on several assumptions, including the representativeness of St. Paul data.
Weakness: Did not obtain data from single sources and single years.

Q3.Assumption: Implicit assumption that the model can be applied to any US city with accessible census data.
Q3.Model: Applies the model developed in Part II to any city, using population size, average home value, and percent of population with bachelor's degrees.
Q3.Results: Biweekly pickup is more efficient than weekly pickup for a curbside program. Small to midsized cities should consider drop off.
Strength and Weakness: Strength: Provides general recommendations applicable to a wide range of cities.
Strength: Highlights the importance of considering local factors.
Weakness: Relies on the assumptions and limitations of the city-level model.
Weakness: Does not address regional variations or specific implementation challenges.
